{{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-075-29-B |Item_parent=Smoking addiction |Item_parent_short=Smoking addiction |Rank=B |Title=Knowing how to look for co-morbidities according to the patient's condition |Description=None |Rubric=Management |Contributors= |Order=29}} In the case of dependence, pharmacological treatment is recommended as it reduces withdrawal symptoms, craving and relapses. It is important to assess psychiatric co-morbidities and co-addictions prior to smoking cessation. *Psychiatric disorders **Schizophrenia 82% of smokers **Bipolar disorder 56% of smokers **Look for anxiety disorders and major depressive episodes. ***there are links between difficulty in quitting and depressive symptoms ***There are anxiety and depressive symptoms induced by withdrawal: **** lasting a few weeks => no pharmacological treatment but support in consultation **** beyond => specific psychiatric treatment **At a distance from withdrawal, improvement in anxiety and depressive symptoms and quality of life.
*Co-addictions **Use or misuse of alcohol and/or cannabis **Other psychoactive substances (in the context of poly-drug use)

question.question: What is an important consideration when treating smoking addiction?
question.option_a: Pharmacological treatment is sufficient to address all aspects of smoking addiction
question.option_b: Assessing psychiatric co-morbidities and co-addictions prior to smoking cessation is crucial
question.option_c: Only patients with a history of anxiety disorders require co-morbidity assessment
question.option_d: Pharmacological treatment only addresses physical symptoms of withdrawal
